title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
added: '''Biden-Ukraine conspiracy theory''' are a series of allegations alleging that former vice president [[Joe Biden]] and his son [[Hunter Biden]] coordinated efforts against anti-corruption investigations in Ukraine into the Ukrainian gas company [[Burisma]].
== Background ==
== ''New York Post'' article ==

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
added: '''Biden-Ukraine conspiracy theory''' are a series of allegations alleging that former vice president [[Joe Biden]] and his son [[Hunter Biden]] coordinated efforts against anti-corruption investigations in[[Ukraine]]into the Ukrainian gas company [[Burisma]].

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
added: '''Biden-Ukraine conspiracy theory''' are a series of allegations alleging that former vice president [[Joe Biden]] and his son [[Hunter Biden]] coordinated efforts against anti-corruption investigations in [[Ukraine]] into the Ukrainian gas company [[Burisma]], which Hunter Biden served on the board of directors from 2014–2019.

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
added: {{uncategorised|date=October 2020}}

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
added: The shop is owned by [[QAnon]]-theory supporter John Paul Mac Isaac. It was left by an unknown person for repair of water damage, but once repair was done the shop had no contact information for its owner, and nobody ever paid for it or came to pick it up.<ref>Business Insider, [https://www.businessinsider.com/new-york-post-may-have-identified-hunter-biden-source-2020-10%3 The New York Post inadvertently identified the original source of its dubious Hunter Biden story].</ref> Criticism has been focused on Isaac over inconsistencies in accounts given by him of how the laptop came into his possession and how he came to give info on it to Giuliani and the FBI.

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
added: ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' reported that according to two "individuals with direct knowledge", multiple senior officials in the Trump administration and reelection campaign were aware of the laptop hard drive "several weeks" prior to the ''Post'' story.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/trump-knew-for-weeks-that-rudy-giulianis-hit-on-hunter-biden-was-coming?ref=home |title=Trump Knew for Days That Rudy’s Hit on Hunter Biden Was Coming |first1=Asawin |last1=Suebsaeng |first2=Erin |last2=Banco |first3=Adam |last3=Rawnsley |website=[[The Daily Beast]] |date=October 14, 2020 |accessdate=October 15, 2020}}</ref>

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
added: According to officials interviewed by ''[[The Daily Beast]],'' then-National Security Advisor [[John Bolton]] told his staff not to meet with Giuliani, because Bolton had been informed that Giuliani was spreading conspiracy theories that aligned with Russian interests in disrupting the 2020 election. These officials were also concerned that Giuliani would be used as a conduit for disinformation, including "leaks" of emails that would mix genuine with forged material in order to implicate Hunter Biden in corrupt dealings.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/john-bolton-warned-staff-to-stay-away-from-russia-aligned-rudy-giuliani |title=Bolton Warned His Staff To Stay Away From Russia-Aligned Rudy Giuliani |website=[[The Daily Beast]] |date=October 16, 2020 |accessdate=October 17, 2020 |first1=Erin |last1=Banco |first2=Spencer |last2=Ackerman |first3=Asawin |first4=Suebsaeng}}</ref>

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
added: ==== Other press outlets ====

[[David Folkenflik]] of [[NPR]] observed that the ''Post'' story asserted as facts things it presumed to be true. He also noted that the lead author of the ''Post'' story, deputy political editor Emma-Jo Morris, had virtually no previous bylines in reporting, and her most significant prior employment was a nearly four-year position as a producer on Sean Hannity’s Fox News program. Hannity, a close Trump advisor, has repeatedly suggested wrongdoing by Biden in Ukraine.<ref> https://www.npr.org/2020/10/17/924506867/analysis-questionable-n-y-post-scoop-driven-by-ex-hannity-producer-giuliani </ref>

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
added: Fellow press outlets ''The New York Times'', ''The Washington Post'' and ''The Wall Street Journal'' stated that they could not independently verify the data provided by ''New York Post''.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Robertson |first1=Katie |title=New York Post Published Hunter Biden Report Amid Newsroom Doubts |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/18/business/media/new-york-post-hunter-biden.html |accessdate=October 19, 2020 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 18, 2020}}</ref>

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
added: Fellow press outlets ''The New York Times'', ''The Washington Post'' and ''The Wall Street Journal'' stated that they could not independently verify the data provided by ''New York Post''.<refname=Robertson>{{cite news |last1=Robertson |first1=Katie |title=New York Post Published Hunter Biden Report Amid Newsroom Doubts |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/18/business/media/new-york-post-hunter-biden.html |accessdate=October 19, 2020 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 18, 2020|archiveurl=https://archive.ph/VtnjX|archivedate=October 19, 2020}}</ref> ''The New York Times'' reported that the ''New York Post'' article was mostly written by Bruce Golding, who refused to be given credit for the article reportedly due to a lack of confidence of its credibility. Gabrielle Fonrouge, who was one of the two employees credited, had little relation to the story, and only learned that she received credit after it was published, reported ''The New York Times''.<ref name=Robertson/>

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
added: ==== Intelligence community ====

On October 19, a group of over 50 former senior intelligence officials, who had served in the Trump administration as well as the three previous, released an open letter stating that the release of the alleged emails "has all the classic earmarks of a Russian information operation."<ref>{{Cite web|last=Bertrand|first=Natasha|authorlink=Natasha Bertrand|date=October 19, 2020|title=Hunter Biden story is Russian disinfo, dozens of former intel officials say|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/10/19/hunter-biden-story-russian-disinfo-430276|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-10-20|website=[[Politico]]|language=en}}</ref>

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
added: {{Verifiability}}

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
deleted: == Allegations of media bias in reporting ==

On October 29, 2020, award-winning journalist [[Glenn Greenwald]] claimed to have had an article draft censored from [[The Intercept]], a media outlet he co-founded in 2013 as editors allegedly called for the "removal of all sections critical of Joe Biden".<ref>https://greenwald.substack.com/p/my-resignation-from-the-intercept</ref><ref>https://greenwald.substack.com/p/emails-with-intercept-editors-showing</ref> Greenwald's article draft was called ''U.S. Media uses falsehoods to defend Joe Biden from Hunter's emails''.<ref>https://greenwald.substack.com/p/article-on-joe-and-hunter-biden-censored</ref> The incidence caused Greenwald to resign from The Intercept. Greenwald commented on his blog that the New York Post story and its aftermath "provoked extraordinary efforts by a ''de facto'' union of media outlets, Silicon Valley giants and the intelligence community to suppress these stories". Greenwald further complained that "modern media outlets do not air dissent; they quash it".<ref>https://greenwald.substack.com/p/my-resignation-from-the-intercept</ref>

[[Matt Taibbi]], another award-winning journalist, objected to the "suppression" of the New York Post story in an October 24 article called ''With the Hunter Biden Expose, Suppression is a Bigger Scandal Than The Actual Story''. Taibbi referred to "unprecedented efforts to squelch" information about the New York Post story, and a "confederation of press outlets whose loyalty to the Democratic Party now overshadows its obligations to inform".<ref>https://taibbi.substack.com/p/with-the-hunter-biden-expose-suppression-136</ref>

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
deleted: ==== Allegations of media bias in reporting ====

On October 29, 2020, award-winning journalist Glenn Greenwald claimed to have had an article draft censored from The Intercept, a media outlet he co-founded in 2013 as editors allegedly called for the "removal of all sections critical of Joe Biden". Greenwald's article draft was called "U.S. Media uses falsehoods to defend Joe Biden from Hunter's emails".<ref>{{Cite news|last=Robertson|first=Katie|date=2020-10-29|title=Glenn Greenwald Leaves The Intercept, Claiming He Was Censored|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/29/business/media/glenn-greenwald-leaving-intercept.html|access-date=2020-10-29|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> The incidence caused Greenwald to resign from The Intercept. Greenwald commented on his blog that the New York Post story and its aftermath "provoked extraordinary efforts by a de facto union of media outlets, Silicon Valley giants and the intelligence community to suppress these stories". Greenwald further complained that "modern media outlets do not air dissent; they quash it".<ref>{{Cite news|last=Barr|first=Jeremy|last2=Izadi|first2=Elahe|title=Glenn Greenwald resigns from the Intercept following dispute over Biden story|language=en-US|work=Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/media/2020/10/29/glenn-greenwald-intercept-resigns/|access-date=2020-10-29|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
added: Investigative journalist [[Glenn Greenwald]] has resigned from his position at [[The Intercept]] over the desire of staff to censor an article he wrote, claiming the quality of the evidence for the New York Post dossier was comparable to many other leaks published by the media.<ref>https://greenwald.substack.com/p/article-on-joe-and-hunter-biden-censored</ref><ref>https://greenwald.substack.com/p/my-resignation-from-the-intercept</ref>

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
added: {{Disputed title|section=RfC: Article scope}}

title: Biden–Ukraine conspiracy theory
added: Journalist [[Glenn Greenwald]], a founder of ''[[The Intercept]]'', left the publication and blamed its editors for violating his editorial freedom by censoring his article related to Hunter Biden's laptop.<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Robertson |first1=Katie |title=Glenn Greenwald Leaves The Intercept, Claiming He Was Censored |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2020-10-29 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/29/business/media/glenn-greenwald-leaving-intercept.html |language=en-US |df=mdy-all }}</ref> ''The Intercept'', which is known for publishing stories against the Democratic Party establishment, had anticipated Greenwald's departure based on declining rapport between him and the organization.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Sterne |first1=Peter |title=Inside Glenn Greenwald’s Blowup With The Intercept |work=[[New York Magazine]] |date=2020-10-30 |url=https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/10/inside-glenn-greenwalds-blow-up-with-the-intercept.html |language=en-us |accessdate=2020-10-31 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
